title: Ticket #3573: Execute directories left behind when privsep is in use
description:
I have tracked this down and I am writing down what I learned:

What we knew going in: execute directories were being left behind for some strange reason. Looking at the StarterLog, it looks like the execute directories correspond to jobs that were hard-killed (kill -9) (or maybe the power went out) -- there is no statement corresponding to the end of a job in the StarterLog.

What I found out: first off, the code was doing the wrong thing. Here is a line from /etc/condor/privsep_config: 

valid-dirs = /var/lib/condor/execute/slot1
The code was doing a simple string comparison against this and "//var/lib/condor/execute/slot1", so the two slashes at the beginning were screwing up the comparison.

Second problem, after I fixed the above: privsep was still barfing. It barfed because of the following: 

$ ls -ld /var/lib/condor
drwxr-xr-x 4 condor condor 4096 Apr 12 00:15 /var/lib/condor
Note that the owner of the directory is condor, but user condor is not in the trusted-uids list in /etc/condor/privsep_config! (The execute directories are under /var/lib/condor/execute on this machine.) Indeed the configuration is 
valid-caller-uids = condor
valid-caller-gids = condor : 1100-1199

valid-target-uids = nobody : boinc : ghostusr : slot1 : slot2 : slot3 : slot4 : slot5 : slot6 : slot7 : slot8 : slot9 : slot10 : slot11 : slot12 : slot13 : slot14 : slot15 : slot16 : slot17 : slot18 : slot19 : slot20 : slot21 : slot22 : slot23 : slot24 : slot25
valid-target-gids = boinc : nobody: ghostusr : slot1 : slot2 : slot3 : slot4 : slot5 : slot6 : slot7 : slot8 : slot9 : slot10 : slot11 : slot12 : slot13 : slot14 : slot15 : slot16 : slot17 : slot18 : slot19 : slot20 : slot21 : slot22 : slot23 : slot24 : slot25 : 1100-1199
So I ran 
# chown root.root /var/lib/condor
# chown root.root /var/lib/condor/execute
Then I restarted the startd, and it cleaned up the execute directories.

Possible solutions/workarounds: condor should be in the valid-target-* lists, or the execute directories should be owned by nobody or root.
remarks:
2013-Apr-12 09:40:17 by nwp:
Pushed onto V7_9-gittrac_3573-branch, which is based off of V7_9_5-branch. Would like to get this reviewed and merged, to be released with htcondor version 7.9.5 if possible.

2013-Apr-12 09:41:19 by zmiller:
the directory may end up owned by condor if for whatever reason the starter is killed while the sandbox is being staged in. the reason for this is that in PrivSep mode, the transfers are done as the condor user and then the sandbox is chowned to the real user. hence, if it gets interrupted there, the directory will still be owned by condor.

i do not see any problem in adding condor to the target user list. the switchboard can only be called by the condor user. the condor user should be able to act on behalf of the condor user without any security implications.

2013-Apr-12 10:00:15 by nwp:
It looks like we don't have a default privsep config in the git tree. Is that something that the CHTC admins create and is puppet-ized?

2013-Apr-12 11:19:32 by zmiller:
CODE REVIEW by zmiller

no major problems. some comments:

MyString.cpp and filesystem_remap.cpp:
these changes were not related to the issue at hand, don't affect the meaning of the code, don't have any drastic improvement in performance, and don't necessarily improve readability. as such, i think this code should have been left alone.

directory_util.cpp, lines 79 and 107:
the conditions (*filename) and (*subdir) are not needed. null != DIR_DELIM_CHAR so the loop will already abort when it encounters a null.

all other changes look good. i do wonder if we should just add a function in condor to compress slashes in pathnames, and then call that when we are done concatenating paths rather than micro-manage each individual addition of them.

2013-Apr-12 11:20:23 by moate:
We currently puppetize the privsep configuration. On a somewhat related note, it would be really nice if the HTCondor RPM created the execute directory with privsep-compatible permissions like so:

/var/lib/condor 0755 root:root /var/lib/condor/execute 0755 root:root

The permissions that the RPM creates those directories with currently allow world-readability, I believe. A startd with privsep configured will not run when that is the case, and it has bitten us a few times (although puppet now handles this correctly).

2013-Apr-12 11:43:33 by nwp:
It looks like the problem is not actually fixed, as jobs are landing on the machine and failing with messages such as 
04/12/13 11:32:25 ERROR "CondorPrivSepHelper::initialize_sandbox: privsep_create_dir error on /var/lib/condor/execute/slot1/dir_17880" at line 101 in file /slots/10/dir_10148/userdir/src/condor_starter.V6.1/condor_privsep_helper.UNIX.cpp
04/12/13 11:32:25 ShutdownFast all jobs.
04/12/13 11:32:25 ERROR "Assertion ERROR on (m_sandbox_initialized)" at line 164 in file /slots/10/dir_10148/userdir/src/condor_starter.V6.1/condor_privsep_helper.UNIX.cpp

2013-Apr-12 13:48:18 by nwp:
Fixed this last one. It turns out the starter assumes the switchboard had a problem if anything is written back from the switchboard. Just had to update to latest version, taking out all the debug statements from the switchboard.
